data.title: Interact with DevTools asynchronously
data.body:
Fixes #9697.

The above issue can be consistently reproduced by switching to Dvorak and trying to open the DevTools through `Cmd-Alt-I` (which, if you have a Qwerty keyboard, is `Cmd-Alt-G`). This doesn't happen on most Qwerty keyboards and, quite oddly, I tracked down the problem to be related to DevTools being opened or closed. Indeed, if we try to replace `ApplicationDelegate::toggleWindowDevTools` with a simple log statement this problem doesn't seem to be reproducible. The reason why only certain keyboard layouts trigger this particular behavior is obscure to me at the moment, but somehow I believe this has to do with the DevTools appearing and disappearing, thereby confusing Chromium's input events. (@zcbenz: maybe you have some ideas on what's triggering this behavior?)

I think this wasn't caused by a recent Electron upgrade, but rather to the way we have changed Atom DevTools interaction: in the past, this was asynchronous but it got changed to be sync during the `AtomEnvironment` refactoring. I switched back to using an asynchronous approach, so that our keybinding/commands event handlers have the chance to fully execute without waiting for DevTools to be opened/closed.

I _think_ we were using a sync version because [these lines of code](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/src/atom-environment.coffee#L672-L674) need to be executed in succession, so that the javascript code can be run when DevTools are already open. It turns out that, before these changes, the console wasn't getting shown if DevTools were closed because we still have to wait until the `devtools-opened` event gets triggered. This PR fixes also this problem by implementing a Promise-based API on top of Electron DevTools API.

/cc: @nathansobo @atom/feedback

data.title: can atom do find action when I select?
data.body:
`visual studio code` automatically does `find` action when I select something and highlight all found result in both editor window and mini map.

This is such a powerful feature that I really love it. Can `atom` do it or has any package implements this feature?

data.title: Screen blinks and some parts become dark
data.body:
Hi,

Since a few versions I got a strange problem. I am running Atom 1.2.3 (such a great tool by the way) under Linux (with Gnome3). I will try to describe what happens :

Sometimes, it's like the main view is blinking. For example, if I go to another tab, some white parts will appear for one second at the bottom and the right of my pane.

Furthermore, if I create a new file/folder (yeah it happens sometimes...), when I start typing the name of my new file in the box dialog, this last one will become completly black. It is a bit disturbing :)

I don't know if these two things are linked, but they start happening at the same time. Guess it starts around the 1.2.0 release, but I really not sure. I try to find another issue linked to this one, but my search was not really prolific...

I will keep looking to from source of this troubles, but if anyone has an idea....

Thanks.

data.title: Build errors relating to momentary internet connection lapses
data.body:
Hi,

I keep getting errors such as:

``` bash
Unable to download https://www.atom.io/api/packages/language-gfm/versions/0.81.0/tarball: getaddrinfo ETIMEDOUT
```

at the stage of running `script/build`, where the `language-gfm` and `0.81.0` fields varies, according to the apm package the build gets caught at. Sometimes these connection errors also occur at the `Installing build modules` or `Installing apm` stage. Now, I know how to overcome this error when compiling manually from source code by simply re-running `script/build`, but I was wondering if there is any option I can pass to `script/build` that will get it to re-attempt to download and install the package it gets stuck at and then continue on with the build. This would be incredibly helpful for those of us writing ebuilds for Gentoo-based systems such as Sabayon Linux. 

Thanks for your time,
Brenton

data.title: Is there a way to disable git feature while running Apm test?
data.body:
While running Apm test for a package living in git repository, it tries to load git repro information. This could cause problem if the git repository is huge:

For example, running `apm test` for `atom-helper` in git repository could take 33 seconds:

```
chenshen@chenshen-mbp2:~/.atom/packages/atom-helpers(master)$ apm test
Error Downloading Update: Could not get code signature for running application
[71910:1123/171631:INFO:renderer_main.cc(200)] Renderer process started
[71906:1123/171631:INFO:CONSOLE(46)] "Window load time: 350ms", source: file:///Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/static/index.js (46)
....

Finished in 33.654 seconds
4 tests, 16 assertions, 0 failures, 0 skipped

Tests passed
```

where as if we rm `.git` folder and rerun it:

```
chenshen@chenshen-mbp2:~/.atom/packages/atom-helpers$ apm test
[72332:1123/172002:INFO:renderer_main.cc(200)] Renderer process started
Error Downloading Update: Could not get code signature for running application
[72328:1123/172002:INFO:CONSOLE(46)] "Window load time: 333ms", source: file:///Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/static/index.js (46)
....

Finished in 0.174 seconds
4 tests, 16 assertions, 0 failures, 0 skipped

Tests passed
```

data.title: Caret ranges not respected properly
data.body:
I've been seeing several issues with caret ranges not being respected in package dependencies.

Several of the `linter-*` packages depend on the [atom-linter](https://github.com/AtomLinter/atom-linter) package, so there are usually several instances of it installed in a particular Atom installation. The issue is that when a package with an older version of the library loads it before a package asking for a newer version loads, the older version is used instead.

For example:
`linter-js-yaml` had version 3.3.7 installed of `atom-linter`, which is perfectly fine for its asked for version of `"^3.3.7"`. When testing `linter-php` which had `"^3.3.9"` specified in its package.json however, I was getting errors that had been fixed in 3.3.8 and checking the trace it showed that it was using the 3.3.7 from `linter-js-yaml`'s installation.

According to [semver's definiton of caret ranges](https://docs.npmjs.com/misc/semver#caret-ranges-1-2-3-0-2-5-0-0-4) a request for `"^3.3.9"` should be equivalent to `">=3.3.9 <4.0.0"`, but Atom is loading `3.3.7` which does not fall within that range.

I've been seeing this on Windows 10 x64, on Atom 1.3.0-beta6. (And older versions of each before in the past).
I think I've seen it before on Ubuntu, but can't verify that at the moment.

If this has already been reported please point me in the right direction as I could not find it.

data.title: Mac OSX - "open with" context menu has all (previous) versions of Atom installed
data.body:
Right-clicking on a file within Finder and selecting "Open With..." shows a sub-menu of suggested applications. All previously installed versions of Atom are listed. Only 1 copy of the app lives in Applications, so it's likely each version of Atom is added to the registered applications list when upgraded, but the old version isn't removed.

![atom bug - open with multiple versions](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2947116/11353714/7ac09ea8-91fa-11e5-914b-0003c1a68746.png)

We solve that bug by customizing Error.prepareStackTrack, where we save the raw stack into error.rawStack field.

Tested following in Atom.app console:

```

e.stack
```

data.title: Implement pylint
data.body: This would be useful run in this text editor

data.title: Analytics for actual package usage
data.body:
Your'e not going to believe this but I'm going to argue for more analytics. 

If you were to capture actual usage of packages, i.e. hours per day for each package, it would provide several big benefits.  It could be presented in the atom.io package listings.  The ratio of downloads to usage would be particulary useful since it would give a good measure of package acceptance. One sort option could be based on usage.
- It would help users pick packages to try.  Help find out which ones have happy users.
- It would help package developers like me to find out which packages to focus on.  If my package had a bad ratio of downloads to usage I would know to improve it or drop it.

I don't see how this makes privacy any worse.

data.title: TextBuffer::getTextInRange() incorrect?
data.body:
This may simply be a misunderstanding, but it seems that `TextBuffer::getTextInRange()` is returning incorrect values.

Let's say you have a file consisting entirely of this:

```
foo
```

Since Ranges are 0 based you would expect the following to return "foo":

``` JavaScript
buffer = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().getBuffer()
buffer.getTextInRange([[0,0],[0,2]])
```

However it only returns "fo". You need to run the following to get "foo":

``` JavaScript
buffer.getTextInRange([[0,0],[0,3]])
```

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/427137/11347810/e960f48e-91d7-11e5-811f-d55ddcc6e5aa.png)

Are ranges not 0 based, or is something not correct here?

data.title: `stylesheet` persists in the treeview
data.body: Immediately after a fresh reinstall of Atom (before installing any packages), after `Edit > Open Your Stylesheet`, a folder or file `stylesheet` is created in the treeview. Copy-paste its full path (from context menu) shows `atom://.atom/stylesheet`. Every time I restart Atom, no matter what files I had open in the previous session, `stylesheet` is in the treeview. I'm using Atom 1.2.3 on Ubuntu 14.04.2 LTS

data.title: suggestion : Check for  python syntax errors like in textwrangler
data.body:
I really like this function.
Hmm while your at it maybe check for all types of python errors?

data.title: Command + N does not open new window on Mac
data.body:
#### Steps
1. Close all currently open Atom windows
2. Press command+n
#### Expected

A new window with a new file should open.
#### Observed

Nothing happens. You must first press command+shift+n to open a window before opening a new file. This is convoluted—everyone understands that command+n means "open a new window".

data.body:

1. ...
2. ...

**Atom Version**: 1.2.3
**System**: Mac OS X 10.11.1
**Thrown From**: Atom Core
### Stack Trace

Uncaught Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/Users/pinky/Library/Application Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.YlYDLmU'

```
At ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:0

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, lstat '/Users/pinky/Library/Application Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.YlYDLmU'
    at Error (native)
    at fs.lstatSync (fs.js:844:18)
    at Object.fs.lstatSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:189:16)
    at realpathSync (fs.js:1454:21)
    at Object.fs.realpathSync (ATOM_SHELL_ASAR.js:272:24)
    at toRealPath (module.js:109:13)
    at Function.Module._findPath (module.js:149:20)
    at Module._resolveFilename (module.js:334:25)
    at Function.Module._resolveFilename (/Users/pinky/Library/Application Support/com.github.atom.ShipIt/update.YlYDLmU/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/module-cache.js:383:52)
    at Function.require.resolve (module.js:388:19)
```
### Commands

```
     -0:00.0 fuzzy-finder:toggle-file-finder (atom-pane.pane.active)
```
### Config

``` json
{
  "core": {},
  "editor": {
    "invisibles": {}
  }
}
```

``` coffee
No installed packages

# Dev
```
